Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2014 07:41AM Lynn1234 wrote: Thank you Dr. Bach and thank you for posting the article. At stage 4, I wish all I had to do was try harder or fight better! Gee, if I would have only known! I am a member of Gilda's and I love my support group. Believe me there are many wonderful women out there who are just having to deal with this the best they know how- many with limited funds, few family members, etc. Gilda's Club helps by being a wonderful resource for support, health and nutrition education and making new friends who can relate and support one another.Â  Amy could have said so much more!
Posts.Title: Oncologist Takes on Amy Robach's Pink Warrior Rhetoric EnglishMajor Marple

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2015 08:25AM - edited Dec 12, 2015 08:29AM by Lynn1234 This will be my third last Christmas. The first one I felt very sad and mopey because i did not have the stamina, felt sick and was sure it would be my last one. The second was better. This year it's been a lot easier because I have more energy. I've put every decoration I have up, made 4different cookie doughs(to bake later-waaaay easier and less tiring), bought or made presents, all in advance to make things less stressful and overwhelming so I can hopefully enjoy the holidays. However-I do all this because in the back of my mind I still feel it may be my last Christmas and if so, then I feel that I need it to be the best one ever. I put so much pressure on myself to make sure my husband and kids have all of our usual traditions, so they'll remember the fun we've had at the holidays. I wish I could lighten up a little, but I have a lump in my other breast that has to be checked out on 12/22. Maybe this frenzy of The holidays is keeing my mind occupied in the meantime ðŸ˜•
Posts.Title: On the subject of "Last Christmas" sueopp artistatheart

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2015 02:48PM - edited Jun 6, 2015 02:54PM by Lynn1234 It could be that the radiologist is not as expert as you, that's why a second opinion would be best. The rate for false negative on 3D is still high. See below from Radiopaedia.org for Radiology professionals: Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) is an imaging technique that allows a volumetric reconstruction of the whole breast from a finite number of low-dose two-dimensional projections obtained by different X-ray tube angles, with a geometric principle very similar to that applied in stratigraphic technique. Despite direct digital mammography (FFDM - Full Field Digital Mammography) has improved the sensitivity of the method, especially in dense breasts, the number of false negatives (FN) is still high, largely due to the presence of dense tissue that may affect lesions conspicuity:
Posts.Title: Am I being paranoid or do I need to pursue this? y1981m art15

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 04:58PM - edited Jun 5, 2015 05:00PM by Lynn1234 You are absolutely not being paranoid-you're being smart and a good advocate for yourself! Get a second opinion. The radiologist said mine was "just a cyst" too. Turned out it was a 5.9 cm tumor and was stage 4. It had already spread to my spine and pelvic area with a compressed vertabra to boot! I don't mean to scare you but, it's better to be safe than sorry to use an old cliche. I really wish that I would have checked it out more thoroughly when they said "just a cyst." May have been caught before it was stage 4. Take care, Lynn

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2015 01:54PM Lynn1234 wrote: I sm on Medicare and a supplemental plan F and a separate prescription policy. It's been great and I am pleasantly surprised! However, it is quite confusing when you are signing up and trying to figure it all out. I am under 65, so it was trickier. Ihad to read the booklet 10 times before it sunk in! I highly recommend an insurance broker. Mine did not charge anything and was so knowledgeable about all the different plans. She made sure the prescription plan covered all my meds and that all my doctors and hospitals were covered. Even if I had to pay a fee, it would have been worth it! Be sure to get a recommendation though. Take care, Lynn 1234
Posts.Title: Medicare Kandy Lynn1234

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2015 12:40PM - edited Nov 29, 2015 12:42PM by Lynn1234 Be wary of complacent doctors! They could be arrogant, lazy, too busy or plain ignorant. Be your own best advocate. Remember there is always one doctor who graduated last in his class!!! Make sure he's not yours. Many breast cancer patients have both blastic and lytic lesions. Bones scans show mainly blastic and CT show lytic. MRI's show both. Not sure about pet scans, never had one. I've always felt that having scans, waiting for results and trying to interpret what they mean is one of the most frustrating things about having cancer! Take care! Lynn1234

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2016 01:15PM - edited Feb 20, 2016 01:16PM by Lynn1234 Thanks Bestbird! I had a feeling there was a study on de novo out there somewhere. I do wish that I would have had scans before my mastectomy. My PCP set me up with the breast surgeon and within a week I had the surgery. Only after that did I see the oncologist, who did scans. I had lots of bone mets in pelvis and back and a fractured vertabra Maybe I wouldn't have had the mastectomy. Some docs don't do mastectomy on stage 4.

Posts.Content: Lynn1234 wrote: Hi everyone! I've been on Xgeva monthly for bone mets for going on 5 years and have developed a very small fracture on the shaft part of my right femur. I've read that Xgeva can cause this, though rarely. It is not very painful at all. It was discovered as a hot spot on a regular bone scan. I then had an xray and MRI to check to see if it was a met or impending fracture. My MO sent me to an Orthopedic Oncologist who knew right away that it was from the Xgeva and took me off the Xgeva for now. Have any of you had a fracture due to Xgeva? Dx 3/26/2013, IDC, Right, 5cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone, 1/27 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

But it sounds like that might be a little premature. I haven't had any progression since my diagnosis, I was stage 4 at diagnosis with mets to spine, pelvis and sacrum. All in my bones.

Posts.Content: May 12, 2015 05:15PM Lynn1234 wrote: I am very claustrophobic and have had many MRI's, including a few brain MRIs. One MRI I had lasted one hour and 20 minutes. It was really hard-kept wanting to press that button to get out! However, I have a few things I do now that help me get through - hope they can help you too! 1. Try not to think about it in the days and hours before the MRI. Keep busy. Divert your thoughts to something else. 2. A thick wash cloth over the eyes helps a lot! 3. Bring a CD of music you can sing or hum to. (No moving or shaking though) ie....Beatles, Motown, a musical, etc. The tech should be able to play it for you during the scan. 4. Once the scan begins, try to meditate, sleep or concentrate on something other than the scan. I planned my daughter's entire wedding during that long one! 5. Get a prescription from your doctor for Ativan. I take two about 45 min before the scan. By the time I get on the table, I am pretty sleepy and usually fall asleep during the scan. Be sure to tell the tech you are going to take it -when you arrive for the scan. Hope this helps!!!
Posts.Title: Cancer and Clustrophobia starbrightlyshines sandilee

Posts.Content: May 22, 2015 03:29PM - edited May 22, 2015 03:38PM by Lynn1234 I've been meeting my best friend for Saturday morning coffee together for over ten years. We've been friends for over 40 years. She's always been so helpful and we've shared our issues and kids problems etc. but, as close as we are, when she starts talking about not being able to choose between carpet colors or vacation spots, I get really depressed. Of course besides the Cancer there are the money issues that go along with it, so no vacation for us or remodeled rooms. I'm not looking forward to our coffees like I used to, sadly. My local Stage 4 support group is on the same wavelength fortunately, so we can let it all out and listen and help each other through this stuff. highly suggest joining a stage 4 group. Best thing I've done for myself since all this began.
